ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Make sure you have the time to shoot and process 35 rolls of film. If you have a busy semester, do not take this course.
Art 136 is a great into class for anyone remotely interested in photography. It's super fun and one of my favorite classes I've taken.
It's hard. Take it. Totally worth it.

This is a great course to learn basic techniques of film photography and to learn how to view and capture the world in a different manner. I learned an incredible amount in this course, but it is definitely a big time commitment.

An introductory photography class that focuses on 3 main areas: 1) how to take photos 2) how to develop/print photos, 3) the history of B&W photo. Great class to take if an art major, as it touches on not only photography but other mediums as well, but also great to take if a non-art major (a majority of the class was not and they enjoyed it). I would recommend this course to another student if they are at all interested in art or photo; even if they are not they will most likely be interested by the end of the course. Good stuff!

TAKE THIS CLASS. You will not receive a better introduction to photo history or photo techniques in any other art course, and it is a foundational jumping off point before you take almost any two-dimensional course -- take this before any other photography classes/film classes/drawing/painting classes. You will learn so much about light, framing, subject matter, and just the brute amount of time required to really get an art form. This class does have a lot of non-condensable time though -- you really cannot rush the process of developing film because there is a set amount of time required. to make negatives will take 45 minutes. There's nothing you can do. I spent about ten hours outside of class a week, which is manageable and enjoyable, but be forewarned. Take the class though. You absolutely will not regret it.
